paper_abstract: The conventional forbidden state problem for discrete event systems is concerned with the issue of synthesizing a maximally permissive control policy to prevent a discrete event system from reaching any forbidden state during the course of its computation. In this paper, we regard the forbidden state problem as a decision problem, and investigate the decidability/complexity issue of the problem under two new types of control policies, namely, non-blocking and fair policies, for finite state systems and Petri nets.
paper_title: Decidability and complexity analysis of forbidden state problems for discrete event systems
